commentBody: Breezy and fun, but it went by too fast and didn't feel like a proper Saturday challenge.

"I forgot how to play pool!"
"Just use some cue cards!"

("Okay! Otherwise, I'd rack my brain.")
Oops, they switched the Friday and Saturday puzzles. 11:42, no mistakes, a Saturday personal best and less than a third of the time Friday took me
Very very easy, no Saturday by any stretch of the imagination.

As a theater kid in more than one way (my parents were active in theater so spent a lot of time in them growing up and did a lot of theater in school) I actually take offense at being labeled a clique. Otherwise fairly easy for a Saturday

I enjoyed this one, and was helped immeasurably by the bird clues.  Anyone who has heard the cry of the BARNOWL in the dead of night won‚Äôt soon forget it.  I screwed myself up royally by having speakon instead of SPEAKOF, which in turn made the intersection if 29A and 30D impossible to fill.  Eventually I knew I had to look elsewhere and saw my mistake.  I might have had a really good (for me)/Saturday time, but for that hiccup.
For "activity requiring a map", I confidently filled in ORIENTEERING, which fits the space and crosses with AGARS and GREER, which I already had.  Of course, every other letter is wrong...

19-Across brought to mind the summer of 1971 when I worked in a physiology lab at Berkeley whose research focus was the pituitary hormone prolactin. For months, they had sacrificed pigeons for their pituitaries, and squab had been a staple of the grad students' dinners. One of the postdocs told me that the saddest day of her life was when she found out that lobsters don't have pituitary glands.
Awfully fast for a Saturday.
Is it just me, or was that way too easy?  New PB.

Here's my uninformed take on the puzzle (uninformed in that I've not yet read the Wordplay column or any comments, but I promise I will):

Fun. Challenging at first; I couldn't find a toehold until 19A SQUAB. Once I got rolling, though, it turned easy and the other answers filled in quickly. It's actually my 10th fastest Saturday ever.

A big thumbs down on the clueing of 25A [Alert to prejudice] WOKE. In my experience, the only people who use WOKE that way use it to belittle people who have more respect for people unlike themselves than the people calling them WOKE have. It's the new "politically correct."

I did like the clue for 44A [Spot-checked?] DOG-SAT (even though I got it quickly).

After Friday‚Äôs puzzle came dangerously close to ending my streak, and took me much longer than I would ever dare to admit, I sailed through this Saturday puzzle with very little trouble. I‚Äôll join those who believe the puzzle orders were reversed. 

TIBERIUS was the middle name of Starship Enterprise Captain James Kirk, played by Montreal native William Shatner. Just a little Trekkie trivia!
Can we stop with swastika imagery finally?

A rather quick Saturday, like many others have said. A lot of the answers seemed familiar, and once they started falling, it completed rapidly. It's been quite a while since I've gone through a Saturday this fast, but it certainly was a fun one.

Thanks, Ryan.
Whoo, that was fast. And fun!

Saturdays can come through, it can happen to you:
Just fill in "YOUNG AT HEART"
It's not hard, you needn't fear, just fill in Garson Greer
(knowing her name means you're only young at heart). 

You can make us all swoon with impossible clues
Turn off Dana Bash, smoke some grass, drink some booze
And wish for the return of Shortz apr√®s each passing day
Got served crab by Jose Andres, with just a dab of Old Bay!

No sir no! I told the yes men, read the op-ed by Masha Gessen
if you're young at heart
But it's hard to be woke when we elected a bloke
who ain't all that young at heart

And you can survive, bypass Project 2025,
think of the joy you'll derive, just from being alive!
But here is the best part, Friday night's a head start
and you can complete this puzzle if you're young at heart!
This was a week of multiple personal bests, including today‚Äôs. Not complaining in the slightest!

Any puzzle that mentions Chef Jos√© Andr√©s and by extension his World Central Kitchen is more than okay by me.

I didn't find this puzzle overly difficult, nor any other puzzle this week. Can't really judge by just one week.  Will have see going forward whether this trend continues or not.
Quicker and easier, as others have said. I do have one gripe though: FERB is Phineas‚Äô step-brother. One could argue that doesn‚Äôt mean they‚Äôre not pals, but it could have been clued better.

After a clunky, clueless start (I entered GREER, took it out and entered Kanin, took it out and put back GREER), I kept some fills and got it going.  There were fun clues that made it worth the TREASURE HUNT (DOG SIT was a honey), and I always like to see an emperor that's not tied up in a toga (penguins are cuter, though).  

There were only a couple of the STALE USUAL SUSPECTS, which was a relief, and I had to stop and scratch my SCRUFFY head a time or two,  because I did get stuck a bit (GLitSY was my first choice for 8A), but that's what makes a puzzle worth the time to solve it.

If you've done 24 Saturdays, Ryan McCarty, you obviously know your way around a grid.  Thanks for keeping us entertained.  I'll watch for the 25th.

As a newer solver (past few months) this was a monumental puzzle. This was the first time I was able to complete a Saturday puzzle - with help of the checker but still a huge milestone for me! 
Agreeing with the other comments, I would say this puzzle is a bit easier than other Saturdays. The first half of the puzzle was a slow burn until I got in some longer central words- then the puzzle really started to fall into place. Great set, thank you Ryan!

I went through this very smoothly until I got to UVEAS crossing BUSS. Is this crosswordese that I'm supposed to have picked up?

Should FYI be clued with an initialism indicator?

‚ÄúToo easy!‚Äù ‚ÄúToo hard!‚Äù Can‚Äôt we all just get along?

I thought this landed somewhere in the middle, i.e. a very reasonable Saturday. There were trivia answers I didn‚Äôt know (UVEAS, LENO), entries I guessed correctly (POOL HUSTLER, TUNA CANS), and enough accessible chew to link the two. No big aha moments here, but a perfectly satisfying solve.

@Caitlin 

It's a good thing you qualified "*most* of our lifetimes" as being post-1980s or I would have said, "Whatchoo talkin' 'bout, Caitlin?" There are quite a few of us out here creaky enough to have GREER be a gimme. 

So here's a dad joke from my childhood, only I told it *to* my dad. (Important to note here, circa 1964.)
"Daddy, what do you get when you put your finger in the president's ear?"
Answer: "Johnson's Wax!"

Only my dad had a dry wit. To my question, he said, "Hm ... 30 days?"
WOKE up, was finished soon after.  Everything just CLIQUEd.

After more than a year solving crosswords daily, this is the first Saturday crossword I could solve solely on my own without googling references or trivia or whatnot. And I was even 8 minutes faster than my average time! A day to remember.

It might be because I'm not an american - but is "NUTSE" the, even slightly correct, spelling of anything. Also i don't understand SAWAS - the internet is no help.

The daddy battle gods took me some time to figure out too ü§î

Now that was hard! In the end I managed to complete the puzzle in reasonable time (24-ish minutes) with just a few lookups - not many were needed as the constructor managed to keep trivia content to a minimum. The clues seemed very tricky to start with but I figured them out, and I'm quite proud of it ü§©.

I found yesterday's puzzle much more difficult - I needed multiple lookups and autocheck on Friday, and today I could keep outside help to an absolute minimum.
Umm, I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs affection that THIRSTY are desperate for üëÄ

Not all that easy for me, of course, but managed to get through it. Guess I shouldn't be surprised that many others did find it unusually quick. 

Couldn't help but note the appropriate crossing of SIRNOSIR and NAM*, but I guess that's just me. *And... with 199 appearances of NAM in a puzzle this is only the second time it's been clued in reference to "Tropic Thunder." And that's a film I'm not familiar with. 

Had a couple of puzzle finds today. Might put those in a reply later. 

..

The stifled 45D you hear?  That's coming from dads everywhere reacting to 27A.  The kinder "corny" was my first thought.

Very quick Saturday for me.  On to other endeavors.
With Thursday and Friday clocking at well over average, it was nice to finish this Saturday in less than half my average time.
My only gripe is the cluing for 48 Across‚Ä¶ pet food? Meow meow I guess.

Typically I detest GIFs, whether pronounced with a hard G or a soft one, whether animated or live-action, whether funny or not. Maybe it‚Äôs because they keep going in an endless loop and I usually find repetition annoying. 

But I guess I‚Äôm just prurient enough to be interested in 29A. Can anyone point me to a short, simple visual (NSFW is OK) about which one would say THAT‚ÄôS A BI GIF?

This was a tough but fun Saturday. I motored through everything but the northwest corner where on my first pass I had C*I*** filled in for 2D (‚ÄúTheater kids, e.g.‚Äù), immediately popped in CRINGE, and then didn‚Äôt think about it again until I had the rest of the puzzle filled in except for a nearly empty northwest corner. 

A confluence of words in that corner I‚Äôve never heard or read anywhere didn‚Äôt help either (BUSS, UVEAS, FERB), but once I figured out that I was unnecessarily bullying theater kids, they eventually fell into place.

I‚Äôm not usually one to take a clue to task, especially when I get the answer,  But ‚Äúsir, no sir‚Äù is the private simply replying to a yes/no question, so I would not classify that as a rejection.
Certainly Zeus, Odin or the Dagda were not "pagan" in their times. I wish I could live long enough only to see the Judeo-Christian god referred to as "pagan."

Is this really Saturday level?  I took a little time in the upper left but the whole thing came together pretty smoothly and quickly.  Fair puzzle, little junk, and a bit of fun, but it seemed a bit too easy/simple.  (I don't have a favorite but the only answer I disliked was battle suits.)

I'll now read what the others have said.  :)

____________________
Jesse Goldberg 8/28/2024 for Puzzle of the Decade
(emu filler)

You had to earn it, but it was a joy to solve. None of the usual suspects, though. So I‚Äôll have to go off and get my own Oreo.
I imagine constructors often feel like donning battlesuits to deal with some of the comments they get. It sometimes feels like a snake pit around here. But if, and that‚Äôs a big if, no one objects, I‚Äôd just like to say I love you, all of you, for making this such a lively place to spend a little time. 
Have a great day and don‚Äôt let the emus bite.

This puzzle was the shots.


(not that I was thirsty)

I was looking on YouTube for a clip of the Roches' wonderful rendition of "Frosty the Snowman," but instead I found this one: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MXfDBH2bij4 Wintry images like these fill me with melancholy: for the passing of my youth, and for the passing of winter conditions such as these, which, with global warming, are becoming less and less common (outside of Hallmark Channel Christmas movies, that is.) Although I've traded my Flexible Flyer for a pair of Karhu X-C skis, I still love playing in snow. Why? I guess, even in my sixties, I'm still Y . . . . "Oh C'mon Bill! Stop being so WOKE! Just think of all that new waterfront property!"

A nice meaty outing. I‚Äôm impressed with those who found it easy; I still had to work at it, so felt like a decent Saturday to me.
We have several OWL varieties around us, who twit away all night. The BARN variety are indeed the noisiest.
I stuck with orienteering for too long at 21D which held me up a little. Love Casablanca but couldn‚Äôt think of the phrase to fit the film. I‚Äôve actually never seen the USUAL SUSPECTS. I‚Äôve refused to watch any films with Mr Spacey in for a long time; his reputation was revealed to us through a family member who had the misfortune to work with him.

Fun finds:
‚Ä¢	Rare-in-crosswords six-letter semordnilap (RECAPS).
‚Ä¢	EARN IT anagrams to TIN EAR in a cool way: Read it backwards for three letters, then read it forward for three letters.
‚Ä¢	SCRUFFY, GLOSSY, THIRSTY, FROSTY, GUTSY ‚Äì Sounds like the B-TIER of Snow White‚Äôs retinue.
‚Ä¢	The cross of two very lovely words (ROBUST, SCRUFFY).

Once again, Ryan‚Äôs grid-building talent shines.  Here‚Äôs an ultra-low-word-count grid (66) -- free of clunky answers.  Look at the huge chunks of white in the grid and how so smoothly the letters fit in!  This is craft and art.  Ryan makes it look easy in his 24 Saturday puzzles, but trust me, it‚Äôs a mountain few can climb.

It‚Äôs fun to look at a long answer with just a few crosses and suddenly realize what it is.  It‚Äôs also fun to take a stab at an answer from a vague clue and have it turn out right.  I had a good number of these moments today, so lots of ‚ÄúWhee!‚Äù

Correctly filling in a puzzle is a happy ending, and better yet is when that happy ending is accompanied by a happy DURING, that is, many buoyant pings throughout the fill-in.  You once again gave me one of those, Ryan.  I had a great time with this, and thank you!
I found today‚Äôs puzzle fun but easy, possibly because my new routine starts with Wordle, then Connections, then the puzzle.  Now I have 3 streaks to worry about! üòÇ

I was amused by the SNAKEPIT, which of course would be a dangerous place for anyone.
So then it was time to imagine different clues:

‚ÄúDangerous place for Paddington Bear‚Äù 
‚ÄúDangerous place for Lady Macbeth‚Äù
‚ÄúDangerous place for Sherlock Holmes‚Äù

It‚Äôs just a weird omission that no snake pit appears in those other stories.
Wow, that was one smooth solve. A fraction of my usual time, but delightful. Enjoyment per minute ratio just fine, in my book.
Too easy. But lovely all the same.

Good Xword Tips for Noobs:  a) Learn the Greek alphabet; b) read both Robt Graves' _I, Claudius_ and _Claudius the God_; c) bone up on myths and legends (if you weren't addicted in childhood), especially noting the antics of PAGAN GODS.

As a P.S., I'd say, "Don't get too fancy."  I wanted 21D's "Activity requiring a map" to be ORIENTEERING (which, alas, fit.)  For 7D I started with YOUTHFUL...um, something.  Oh well.

BARN OWLS-- beautiful birds!  But screech owls got their name honestly.  Maybe we could arrange a contest....?

I thought you just put OLD BAY in the pot of water and then heartlessly dropped the crabs in...  I'm allergic, so I skip over all RECIPEs involving crab.

"Theater kids" form a CLIQUE?  Hmm.  Our son (computer engineering major) had a large number of buddies in the Theater department, so... not all that exclusive.  Maybe it was all the puns..

Nice puzzle, Ryan McCarty.  Reall enjoyed it.

When I entered SWOONS for ‚ÄúReacts like a superfan‚Äù, I immediately thought of The Beatles. so I smiled when I saw today‚Äôs photo. 

I like the crossing triple stacks. especially POOL HUSTER and USUAL SUSPECTS. Great clues for both. Was there ever a film with so many memorable quotes as Casablanca?  "We'll always have Paris" is my favorite. 

When GREER Garson starred in a film with Clark Gable he quipped ‚ÄúI put the arson in Garson‚Äù and she countered with ‚ÄúI put the able in Gable‚Äù. Talk about wordplay!
This one drove me bonkers. Crazy. Wacko. NUTSO! trying to gain a toehold. Mr McCarty you're an evil genius.
Can't believe I completed it!  Sly, subtle, and surprisingly substantive puzzle (e.g. not GLOSSY).
On the dubious proposition that ‚Äúcovering‚Äù could mean name, I had OLDBAT for ‚Äúcrab covering.‚Äù
Challenging but fun puzzle.  As I was finishing I was certain I was going to get the Try Again screen, but instead I got CONGRATULATIONS! after only 16 minutes or so.
Correction: (i.e., not GLOSSY) instead of (e g. not GLOSSY)

Spelling 17A took far too long.

Circa 1966 I watch a POOLHUSTLER win  his opponents car.  I thought, and huh, I just come her to shoot a little 9 ball.

Nice one Ryan
What an thoroughly enjoyable and much needed diversion from the decidedly nasty beginnings from the slough of despond. Nice crossword.
I liked it, maybe that's because I cleared it in about 1/3 my average Sat. I'll still take it over yesterday's puzzle. Also the grid layout was very pleasing.
"Nutty' rather than NUTSO had me tied up for a hot minute in the upper right. Still a good time. Too fast - out of excuses. I have to go clean. Yes, I'm OCD!

Apparently, our home internet kicked out in the middle of my puzzle-solving. I only noticed it when I completed the puzzle, got a completion screen, but no Happy Music or Gold Star. I used my phone's mobile hot-spot to access wordplay. 

Now I see in my stats that I completed today's puzzle in 6'11"--a new personal best! 

I was fast, but not that fast.

I came through the brain fog after hip surgery only to fall to Covid and a new but shorter round of brain fog. So this was my first Saturday completion, and it was a thrill to be back in the saddle again. Unlike the reviewer when I saw Garson, I knew immediately that it was Greer. I guess age has its advantage. I‚Äôve made it to 84, and the little gray cells still seem to be working.

Half my average Saturday time but I loved every minute. Really delightful! Always nice to ponder two great films. ‚ÄúPrivate rejection?‚Äù was a favorite clue, but top marks for the clearest and most succinct definition of WOKE. How can anyone be offended by alertness to prejudice? Bravo, and may the emus and pagan gods approve.

Immensely enjoyable.  This was filled with clues that sparked real curiosity before I got the answer and provided nice Aha Moments once I did. Some of my favorite clue-answers:  POOL HUSTLER; YOUNG AT HEART; SAGAS; and DOGSAT.  USUAL SUSPECTS provoked a lot of curiosity in me since I couldn't come up with it, but afterwards I had the strong feeling: "Shoulda known it!!"

I see only now that I had a DNF.  NUTSy instead of NUTSO (who says that?) gave me LE?Y for the Mark Twain prize winner.  All I could think of was one of the LEVYs in "Schitt's Creek", and I know they're Canadian (!) -- but even so, they're really, really funny.  I wanted ANDRES, not AvDRES for the restaurant guy, but who is LENY?  I know LENNY, but not LENY.  Shoulda seen my mistake, but it was yet again another idee fixe that I failed to correct.  

Doesn't matter.  I had so much fun with this that I was truly sorry when it was over.
Hmm, I wonder how many people revel about how quickly they can chug-a-lug a glass of fine wine.

Not that easy, not knowing about OLD BAY, UVEAS, REF, SEAT FILLER, nor the names (except Greer Garson and Tiberius) and the slang. 
I have read the comments for answers - maybe it's just me? - found OLD BAY online, but welcome explanation of the others.
Thinking back to my first job and my disappointment upon learning that I had not in fact been hired as a bussboy.

Leia: "Why, you stuck-up, half-witted, SCRUFFY-looking nerf herder!"

Han: "Who's SCRUFFY-looking?"

Why yes, I am a Harrison Ford superfan. Can't say I'd SWOON for him, though.

Pretty friendly for a Saturday. Had SPEAKON instead of SPEAKOF, which made THATSABIGIF take too long. Didn't understand "Anchor, e.g." for RACER until I scanned the column, but REAR was the only "Seat filler" I could muster.

Knew TIBERIUS only from James T. Kirk. Sad to admit this.

Other than the NE corner the chewiest for me I've not much to add to the commentary, so I'll let Frank say it. . . 

"Fairytales can come true, it can happen to you
If you're young at heart
For it's hard, you will find, to be narrow of mind
If you're young at heart

You can go to extremes with impossible schemes
You can laugh when your dreams fall apart at the seams
And life gets more exciting with each passing day
And love is either in your heart, or on its way

Don't you know that it's worth every treasure on earth
To be young at heart
For as rich as you are it's much better by far
To be young at heart

And if you should survive to a hundred and five
Look at all you'll derive out of being alive
And here is the best part, you have a head start
If you are among the very young at heart"
When I noticed the puzzle was by Ryan, I thought to myself it will be an above or way above  average solve time. Not today-nice puzzle!

It must indeed have been an easy puzzle. Even I (someone who has deteriorated enough to answer "octopus" instead or "waterfall" for "might freeze in cold weather" in a Japanese crossword yesterday with the first square of two, TA, given! Then I made exactly the same pronunciation mistake for today's "sushi roll"!) finished before bedtime (in 29:36) using Autocheck. I could probably have done as well without Autocheck when I was 84.

I would argue that dad jokes are not stale; they are classic.

I might lose that argument.

A note on UVEAS. Every solver brings a unique life experience to the table. One solver‚Äôs Natick is another‚Äôs gimme. For reasons too long to list, I took a full semester three unit course called Structure and Function of the Eye at the tail end of a Liberal Arts degree. How weird is that?
Personal best or just too easy? I finished this Saturday puzzle in  less than thirty minutes.  Now what am I supposed to do all weekend?!
The NYT crossword comments page: a never ending source of dime store erudition.
Uveas? Buss?? I‚Äôve never heard of half of these! Poor clueing. Bad puzzle. üëéüèºüëéüèº
"trivia from most of our lifetimes (very little from before the 1980s, anyway)." There are more of you now? Who knew?

After reading just a quick sampling of comments I see that many folks had a fairly fast solve time on this. I had sort of a medium time, but I really enjoyed it and didn‚Äôt get as frustrated as I often do for a Saturday puzzle. Only a few gimmes‚ÄîI‚Äôm old enough that GREER Garson was one of my first spots to get a toehold. Last corner to fill was the NE, where my love of the Indiana Jones franchise helped me out. Thanks for a delightful puzzle Ryan. It was a joy to solve on a pretty gloomy and very wet day.

when yesterday's puzzle was so fun and breezy, my son and i worried that today's would be a real doozy. what a lovely surprise, then, to have so much fun on a saturday. what a great weds-thurs-fri-sat of puzzles we've had this week! 

and with thanks to my long-gone mother, who passed on her love of 1940s movie classics, including "mrs. miniver," starring greer garson. ‚ù§Ô∏èüé•

A Saturday crossword that didn't kill my spirit? ILOVEYOU,  Mr McCarty, and a huge BUSS from me! 

Someone wrote in a previous crossword that you can search the comments to see if a particular clue had been discussed but I can't figure out how to do this. Is that possible on a mobile device?
Nice puzzle.  Fast solve time.  Only gripe is 46A TUNACANS.  Tuna is not pet food.  It's human food often fed to pets as a treat.
Favorite Saturday puzzle by far. Clever clues. Thank you to Mr. McCarty, editors, and tech team.

The word "racism" fit in the squares used for "recipe."

Since it is probably handed down within families, I paused and had a think.

But nah, I realized it would be too controversial.

Wonder if the emu will snag this comment...

This is a day late, but I had  to post that I just received my first Queen bee rating from the spelling bee.  I am so often just made by the odd words that turn up, often with prefixes or suffixes that I don‚Äôt consider to be real words, even if they are in the dictionary, but this was all on my own.
I believe this is the first Saturday I‚Äôve completed without any lookups! Fun puzzle and great past time while I‚Äôm off the 8-down :)

OCD is famously treated with Exposure Response Prevention (ERP), often just called Exposure Therapy. Many of us are more familiar with ERP for phobias.

Think of a person with arachnophobia, they might first talk about spiders, then look at photos, then see preserved specimens, then be in the room with a live spider in a terrarium. The body gets used to the hyper-arousal and habituates. For some OCD cliches, think of not hand washing as frequently, or putting up with distress after a handshake without using hand sanitizer.

The APA holds this as the gold standard treatment for OCD. Not CBT. Your brain unlearning the fight/flight response through repeated exposures is the most effective treatment and this an intentional triggered state of hyper-arousal.

If you or someone you know is diagnosed with OCD, don't look for a CBT therapist (the most commonly advertised, and useful for many disorders thus the starting point for many therapists). Look for someone who advertises a knowledge of ERP.
Had NUTTY instead of NUTSO for the longest time. Who says "nutso" these days?
Incidentally, Saturday's mini was surprisingly tough. Needed a couple of look-ups (including figuring out 1D if not Mai taiS - hey, I don't drink) and even using the autocheck multiple times.
Almost broke my saturday record with this one. Fun puzzle!
It will be a big if when I break my Saturday record. NUTSO! Great puzzle and I loved many of the entries. DOGSAT was cute.
BATTLE SUITS? I promptly filled in 'exoskeleton' at 32A and got the whole middle of the grid messed up for a while.

Northwest corner took the longest even though I had the three top acrosses, but with a lot of trial and error got there eventually. My first Saturday solve without help or lookups. Now I have at least one from each weekday. Time for a little celebration!
@Liz B I missed a personal best by 7 seconds.

@Mike 
I felt for a moment that you would make a mass√© of this pun, but now I rack it up to your vast experience.

@Mike
Give me a break!

@Mike

You're so good with English! We can always bank on that!

I've always felt that your witty puns are right in the pocket. Always nice to visit your corner of Comments.

Solid.

@Becca

I think 'felt' needed quotation marks

Steven,

A fair number of folks thought the Wednesday and Thursday puzzles got switched, so why not Friday and Saturday too?  My water clock is not precise, but this one seemed to me to go faster than yesterday's too.
@Steven M. I think they switched the Saturday and Wednesday puzzles.  Like you said, a really quick one. All you needed was a few crosses to get the long ones.

@Steven M. 

Everyone has their personal strong and weak spots, but for me, things were normal with these past two puzzles.  Friday's took me just about two minutes faster than Saturday's.
@Steven M. Same here, 11:43.

@Steven M.  It can be crazy some weeks, but different strokes for different folks.  My fastest to slowest this week has gone Monday, Wednesday, Tuesday, Saturday, Friday, Thursday (with Sunday yet to come).  Really, how often does a week ever go in a "clean" order?

@Geoff 
I do have my averages increasing in strict Monday to Sunday order so all seems to be working fine and differences are normally just natural variation

@Laura Stratton 

I'm trying to come up with a theory as to how such an easy puzzle got assigned to a Saturday. Are they just mixing things up for variety?
@Megan What an odd thing to take offense over.
@Alex In fairness to her, it was an odd way to clue clique.

@Ed 

The New Oxford American Dictionary defines CLIQUE as "a small group of people, with shared interests or other features in common, who spend time together and do not readily allow others to join them."

Everything before the "and" fits high school "theater kids." I had no interest in theater in high school, so I don't know if the final clause is at all descriptive of those groups.

But it struck me as a bit odd, too.
Depending on the high school, I think most groups have the potential to be cliquey.

@Megan

As a fellow former theater kid I think what rubs me the wrong way about the clue is that theater is where kids could fit in even if they had been rejected by whatever other cliquey groups wouldn‚Äôt have them. So, I‚Äôm sure some theater kid groups can be cliquey but I don‚Äôt think they are a great example either.
@Justin  Agree.  In my experience, theatre kids  are the least clique-y of high schoolers.

@LarryF

At our high school, it was the SUB-groups within ‚Äútheater kids‚Äù who got cliquey. Actors vs techies. Within techies, electricians vs carpenters. Musical theater people being their own thing altogether.

@Marshall Walthew 
I also had SPEAK ON and could not see my way clear to the BIG IF.

@Marshall Walthew 

"Distinctive screech" does not even begin to describe the blood curdling sound.  I welcome all other animals to my neighborhood, but I'm glad BARN OWLs just pass through occasionally.  Being lulled to sleep by some BARRED OWLS is more my speed.

@Hardroch - Interesting recording! 

I'm pretty sure the caw-like sounds are their courtship calls.

Fact Boy,

How many did she have to check to come to that conclusion?

@Fact Boy 
I was a neuroscience major in college back in the seventies and I‚Äùll never forget the neurobiology lab where we performed measurements of action potentials in the tails of lobsters. To the shock of many (and to some, delight), at the end of the lab the professor steamed our subjects and served them up with melted butter. ü¶û

@JohnWM

Since lobsters were never used in research, she had to wait until she had a job that paid enough for her to buy her own.

@Hardroch 

My high school biology teacher found a store that sold Italian specialties and brought a can of sea urchin gonads to class, put them on a plate, and passed it around for us to try. I believe I was the only one who did. Late in life, I worked for NMFS and went on day trips on the Cordell Bank whose objective was to collect adult female yellowtail rockfish. I came home from those trips with 10 pounds of filleted (male) rockfish for home use.

@Hardroch - I have done that lab, and also the one with the claws. My comparative physiology course was nicknamed comparative gastronomy -- we always cooked and ate the animals we used, often right in class. 

One delayed treat was the EEL, which had to go into the smoker and was shared the following week. 

I made whelk ceviche in class (it's just like conch), lobster, smoked eel, and (I shudder to write this...) steamed clams. Among other things. 

I suspect this would not pass muster in today's academic environment.

I joined Team Fiend about two months ago. I‚Äôm enjoying the experience. My regular gig is Brendan Emmett Quigley‚Äôs twice-weekly puzzles (which are worth doing if you don‚Äôt mind a lot of pop culture in your puzzles). 

I‚Äôve also stepped in for other reviewers lately and have blogged a few New Yorker puzzles, a NYT and an AVCX. 

The blogging has increased my admiration for the work that Deb Amlen, Sam Corbin and Caitlin Lovinger do. It‚Äôs harder than I thought to write something that feels like it might be informative and entertaining. And I don‚Äôt have the pressure of a deadline or minimum and maximum word counts!

@Super8ing There are varying definitions of what is considered PAGAN, but mostly they have nothing to do with what is the "one true religion". https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/pagan As you can see, PAGAN can be descriptive of anyone who historically followed a non-monotheistic religion (thus, the clue qualifies) or was a believer in a god other than the the Abrahamic one that Jews, Muslims and Christians believe in. Other than to describe neo-PAGAN religions like Wicca, the term PAGAN is largely outdated and should only be used historically. Certainly, it can be an offensive and dismissive word. I wouldn't advise, for example, referring to Hindus as PAGANS. However, I don't think the clue is incorrect for the entry. If that is indeed what you're implying.

@Steve L Actually my comment really meant to highlight the futility, and historically tragic consequences of "faith." BTW Hinduism is a broad term and like Buddhism, is not, per se, a theistic religion.

@Super8ing 
"Pagan" traditionally means "not Christian," so it wouldn't make sense to refer to the Abrahamic God as "pagan." Specifically, "pagan" has been used to refer to the European belief systems that predated Christianity. Its original meaning was "rural" or "rustic," the sort of people who were out of touch with the new religion. And yes, Zeus was in fact considered pagan in his time--the rise of Christianity overlapped with worship of the old Greco-Roman gods.

@Katie 

I never understood why we were taught in Polish school that monotheistic religions - especially Catholic Christianity, which is most popular over here - are more "advanced" than polytheistic ones. Also, Catholics may claim they are monotheists, but really, Mary, Jseus, the saints, archangels, seem to me to be analogues of the multiple deities of polytheism. You want your eyesight to improve? You pray to... St. Lucy. She may not be officially recognized as the deity of sight, but isn't she one, effectively?
@Super8ing i thought the exact same thing. May that day come sooner than later!

@SteveG_VA 

I guarantee you that most of the people who post their times‚Äîespecially those with times in the super low range‚Äîare not rushing to finish. It‚Äôs just how fast we go. 

It‚Äôs like asking why we don‚Äôt drive 10 mph all the time so we can appreciate our surroundings better. 

Understand that once a solver gets to the point where they can always solve the puzzle, the streak no longer is a measure of your improvement. It just shows how long you‚Äôve been solving on the app. For example, David Connell will always be about 200 days ahead of me until one of us stops solving for one reason or another. It doesn‚Äôt mean he‚Äôs better than me, only that he started using the app about half a year earlier than I did. 

At that point, faster solving speeds are the only way to monitor improvement.  Faster solving means that you can see tricks faster and have a better vocabulary than you once did. 

You go slowly if you want, but don‚Äôt find fault with people because they solve faster than you. It doesn‚Äôt mean they‚Äôre speeding through the puzzle.  

I can savor the solve and the cleverness of the clues when I‚Äôm done, and extend my time by participating in the comments. 

9:45 today without rushing.
@Steve L I was thinking that Steve G was commenting on 27 down A round that is finished quickly and noting that some may finish a round of other beverages quickly.
@SteveG_VA "I'd rather chug-a-lug a mug of Budweiser beer"

@Steve L 

Pretty interesting.  I may never reach that point, and I think I'm happy about that.

While I have managed to complete the puzzle every day so far without aid (I've never looked up anything), there are still lots of days where I think I may fail, and it will probably happen eventually.  So the "streak" for me is a tenuous thing.  I've also never turned on the timer, because it kills ALL the fun for me to feel rushed when I'm trying to enjoy and savor every clue of a puzzle.  I don't want to compete with anyone either.

So maybe I don't envy those who are better at this after all.  :)

This seems to work for me, using an iPad and the Safari browser:

1) Scroll to the bottom of the comments (earliest or latest depending on how you prefer to view them.

2) Put the word you‚Äôre looking for in your browser‚Äôs search bar.

3) Hit Search. Safari gives me a list of suggested sites, a list of bookmarks, and ‚Äî at the bottom ‚Äî Find on page. That last one should take you to the first comment that has your word. 

I don‚Äôt think this will pick up any replies that are hidden under the View more replies button. To do that, you‚Äôd have to first scroll through and expand any reply threads that are condensed. 

Pretty user-friendly, right?
